text: Europe has a common set of rules on how
to deal with asylum seekers it applies
to most EU Member States some
neighboring countries but not the UK in
Ireland the so-called Dublin regulation
is a key part of that system it was
designed to prevent asylum seekers from
submitting applications to multiple EU
Member States it stipulates that asylum
claims should be processed by the
country that played the biggest part in
the applicants entry to the EU usually
the country where they first arrived but
many say the system isn't working why
because of the roots migrants take
asylum seekers first arrived in the EU
in a few countries mainly around the
Mediterranean countries like Greece and
Italy are struggling to process and
accommodate all the arrivals Germany has
now become the first country to suspend
the Dublin regulation saying it doesn't
work and the EU has said that the system
needs to be restructured to spread the
burden new governments have agreed to
take in 32 and a half thousand asylum
seekers over the next two years under a
quota system but they will only take in
refugees from Syria and Eritrea and in
July alone more than a hundred thousand
migrants arrived on Europe Shores
so some countries have taken the matter
into their own hands
Hungary and Bulgaria have been building
fences along their borders to keep
migrants out Slovakia has been
discouraging Muslims from seeking asylum
